CatDescriptText: Mr. Floyd Brindle, engineer, East Liberty and Mrs. Jean Fletcher, housewife, Homestead, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, December 30, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think the Christian Church is doing an effective job in improving racial amity in the city, nation and throughout the world?" Mr. Brindle's answer reads: "This is the question I have been facing as president of a congregation in church.  We have made great advancements in the past few years, but we still have a long way to go."  Mrs. Fletcher's answer reads: "Some churches are, but churches in general, should organize in order to promote better understanding among people of all races."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Floyd Brindle wearing dark fedora, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Jean Fletcher wearing dark sweater and leopard patterned coat, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
